dataset.title: Winter and summer comparison of biological, chemical, and physical conditions in seasonally ice-covered lakes

creator.organizationName: Leibniz Institute of Freshwater Ecology and Inland Fisheries
Leibniz Institute of Freshwater Ecology and Inland Fisheries

abstract.para:
The goal of this data collection was to compile diverse existing data in order to summarize and contrast ecologically relevant parameters in lakes during ice-on (winter) and ice-free (summer stratification) periods. There are 89 unique lakes in this dataset, ranging from small, shallow lakes to large, deep lakes. Lakes are from eleven different countries, primarily in North America and Europe; Antarctica is the only southern hemisphere location represented in the dataset. Variables collected include physical, chemical, and biological, as well as a suite of metadata variables. Chlorophyll a data are particularly well-represented across lakes, while many variables (e.g. zooplankton variables) are only available for a smaller subset of lakes. Temporal coverage for unique lake/sample stations range from one year to a span of 73 years, with 20 lake/stations having at least 30 years of data.
Synthesis analyses based on this dataset are available in: Hampton et al. (2016). Ecology under lake ice. Ecology Letters. doi: 10.1111/ele.12699. It must be stressed that the data here are not raw values from the original sampling, but aggregated values, based on varying initial sampling efforts and protocols, calculated by individual researchers. Please carefully review Supplemental Document S1 and the methods described in Hampton et al. (2016) for detailed information about how data were collected and aggregated, as well as units associated with each variable.

intellectualRights.para:
This dataset provides biological, chemical, and physical data for a wide array of lakes, with extensive spatial and temporal coverage. Synthesis analyses are available for review in: Hampton et al. (2016). Ecology under lake ice. Ecology Letters. doi: 10.1111/ele.12699. This dataset is available for further analysis. Please consider contacting one or all of the contacts if you are interested in collaborating on related or new topics with this dataset.
Please note that 13 datasets included in Hampton et al. 2016 are not able to be publicly published at this time. These include one long-term dataset from Lake Baikal and short-term datasets for 12 lakes in Minnesota (Bellevue, Blakesly, Frolund, Leverson, Mavis West, Morrison, Murk, Org, Pisa, Skunk, Todd North, and Todd South). For information about the 12 Minnesota lakes, please contact Leah Domine (domi7653@stthomas.edu).
For copies of data aggregation instructions and format template submitted to project participants, see Supplemental Information (Doc S1) for Hampton et al. 2016.
Please note that the data here is provided "as is" and future users may need to filter and otherwise subset the data to suit their needs. For example, there are zero values in this data set for variables which may in fact simply be below detection limits, as well as non-zero values that may be below most modern detection limits (e.g. TDP < 1 ug/L). Users are encouraged to use their expert judgement in cases of potential outliers. Additionally, a careful reading of the information provided by researchers in the "comments" and "narrat" fields for each sample/row in this dataset will facilitate decision-making about which data subsets are most appropriate, depending on research question. For instance, net size may have consequences for zooplankton proportions (i.e. rotifers) and labratory methodology may impact results (e.g. dissolved nutrients).
For specific information about the data subset used in Hampton et al. 2016, please see the analysis scripts on Github (DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.179248) or contact Stephanie Hampton.

section.title: Data aggregation
section.para: The primary goal was to compare ecological productivity between ice-covered (winter) and ice-free (summer) periods. Therefore, data was aggregated seasonally; for a given sampling station in a given year, there are usually two rows of data observations: ice-on and ice-free, where the ice-on data is an aggregate of all observations taken under ice and the ice-free data is an aggregate of all observations taken from the stratified period (or a comparable summer period) in that lake and station. Each column is a summary of data: sample data were aggregated for each time period across a depth range (the photic zone). Ice-on summary averages were calculated from data collected under ice, whereas ice-free summary data were calculated from data collected under stratified summer conditions. This qualifier, i.e., that the water body during the ice-free period also be stratified, helps to standardize a typical representation of ice-free lake biology, avoiding the periods of most extreme seasonal transitions.

If the ice period spans two calendar years, “year” refers to the ice-off year (e.g. if the ice season covered December 2014 through March 2015, “year” is counted as 2015; there are separate columns for the start and end dates of each season that reflect the actual dates of the season). When multiple stations were sampled in a given lake and/or if multiple years of data were available for any given station, these additional data were entered as additional rows (pairs of ice-on and ice-free columns).

This dataset includes a "pool station" key to indicate which stations can be grouped together. In these cases, reserachers identified stations which could be aggregated to form a single "functionally distinct" station for analysis purposes (e.g. a set of different stations fall under the same "pool station"). Note that if stations were not able to be pooled together, then the entry in the "pool station" column is the same as the station name.
See Supplemental Document S1 in Hampton et al. 2016 for more information.

methodStep.instrumentation: Metadata variables: year, season, researcher, lake name, lake region, lake country, lake area, lake mean depth, lake max depth, lake elevation, watershed area, water residence time, lake fetch, sample station distance (from shore), station name, station depth, station latitude, station longitude, multiple stations (y/n), start sample aggregate day/month/year, end sample aggregate day/month/year, ice duration, number of samples in aggregate, sample narrative (e.g. notes on sampling protocol), sample type (in situ or remote sensed), photic depth, sampled depth, ice depth, snow depth, ice narrative (e.g. ice clarity notes), stable isotope/fatty acid/gut data associated with aggregate (y/n), and food web narrative.

Physical/chemical variables: water temperature, air temperature, average/cv radiation, average/cv secchi depth, average/cv/max total phosphorous, ave/cv/max total dissolved phosphorous, ave/cv/max total nitrogen, ave/cv/max total dissolved nitrogen, ave/cv/max total dissolved organic carbon, ave/cv/max specific UV absorbance, ave/cv/max water color, ave/cv/max chlorophyll a, water chemistry narrative (of methods), and profiles available (y/n).

Biological variables: ave/max phytoplankton primary production; report units and ppr rates and narrative; phytoplankton sampling method; ave/cv/max phytoplankton biomass; ave/cv/max phytoplankton cell count; proportion of chlorophytes, cryptophytes, cyanobacteria, diatoms, dinoflagellates, and other phytoplankton; ave/cv/max ciliate biomass; ave/cv/max ciliate cell count; ave/cv/max heterotrophic nano-flagellate biomass; ave/cv/max heterotrophic nano-flagellate cell count; narrative of zooplankton sampling method; ave/cv/max zooplankton biomass; ave/cv/max zooplankton count; proportion of daphnia, other cladocerans, cyclopoids, calanoid copepods, rotifers, and other zooplankton; ave/cv/max bacterioplankton cell count; ave/cv/max bacterioplankton production; reporting units and method for bacterioplankton production; narrative of bacterioplankton composition; benthic substrate; ave/cv/max benthic algal biomass; ave/cv/max benthic Chl-a; benthic macrophyte biomass; density of Amphipoda, Gastropods, Bivalvia, Insecta, and Oligochaeta; and narrative of any relevant fish data.
